title: Polly Hudson: Let’s all applaud a hard man’s tears for his late wife
text:

When you’re missing someone desperately, you cling on to any connection to them.

Tanya Jones loved The X Factor, so that’s why her husband Vinnie was taking part in it, as a tribute to Tanya, her legacy.

He was also probably there because he didn’t know where else to be...

When a loved one is seriously ill, their illness becomes your full time job. Afterwards, the days are long and empty.

And so Vinnie took to the stage on The X Factor: Celebrity last Saturday, just three months after losing his wife of 25 years.

Forget sadness in his eyes – heartbreak and pain was written all over his entire face, in capital letters, bold type.

His clothes looked sad. His shoes, his watch, his hat. No one looking at him could have been in any doubt this man was broken.

He could have hidden away. I’m sure people tried to persuade him to, said it was too soon.

But here he was, standing in front of hundreds, performing to millions at home.

He wasn’t the best singer. He was at anything but the top of his game. But he was real. And for that, Vinnie Jones must be applauded. If a bloke famous for being a hard man tough nut can show himself at his most raw and vulnerable, that can only be a good thing.

For all of us.

My son split his head open in the playground earlier this year, when he was in Reception.

At every step of the process of getting him put back together – the school nurse, the staff at A&E, the doctor who treated him – I noticed the same thing. They all told him to be brave. They commended him when he wasn’t crying.

A four-year-old, covered in blood, hurt and scared, was basically repeatedly told to Man Up. And let’s be honest, Man Up means Shut Up, doesn’t it? I doubt anyone who told him to be brave meant any harm, it’s simply an automatic response at this stage.

The point is, it shouldn’t be. And intended or not, it is doing harm.

Men need to know it’s OK for them to have feelings, and to show them. That they don’t have to be strong, or silent. If they’re hurting, cry rather than holding it inside.

Because the terrible truth is you can’t hold it inside for ever. It will come out in some way, shape or form – slowly seeping over years, or in terrible explosions. It doesn’t just magically go away.

In 2015, 75% of all UK suicides were male – it’s the single biggest killer of men under 45 in this country.

That can’t be a coincidence.

Hope sometimes rears its head in the most unlikely places. An ex-footballer on a past-its-prime talent show must be one of the most surprising so far.

But that’s where we find ourselves.

It was clearly incredibly difficult for Vinnie Jones to get through that performance.

Now it’s up to us to make it count.
description: Men need to know it’s OK for them to have feelings and show them
